content.description: A pleasant v0 just right of The Segment, on the small, uphill side of the boulder. I thought this climbed better, and had cleaner fall potential than The Segment. Probably the better beginner problem of the two, althought both would be quite nice for someone without much experience.
content.location: Center of small uphill face of The Cube boulder.

content.description: Ascends the right side of the tall, flat face to the left of the trees. Start from a small triangular left-hand hold and a low, sloping right-hand side pull.
content.location: Climb up the rocky gully above the Cube boulder to a small cluster of trees roughly halfway up the cliff.

content.description: Start sitting under the incredible overhanging prow feature with a good right hand edge/pinch and left hand crimper. Compress your way out the prow with wide heel hooks and difficult slaps to a crux move to the slightly better sloper on the right.
content.location: From the trailside boulder of Bowl Weevil (V3), head up and slightly left to pick up the trail that is used to access the top of Clamshell Cave. Follow this uphill for approximately 5-7 minutes and look for cairns near a jumble of boulders once you are past the top of the crag.

content.description: I thought this was the best of the three big lines on this boulder (The Cube, Cube Crack, and this). Start on big holds a few feet right of the crack, and weave your way through the line of least reistance to finish high and slightly right. Great movement and rock, and you get high enough to notice it on this line. Excellent.
content.location: Right of Cube Crack on The Cube boulder.

content.description: Fun hand crack problem for me the crux was getting down : ) tree can be helpful in the descent.
content.location: on the north side of the Cube boulder wich is located at the NE corner of the crag.

content.description: Traverse the overhanging lip until it comes to a point.  The crux comes when you mantle on the left side of the point.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, nice flat landing pretty safe.
content.location: Scram is the only problem on a very obvious looking boulder in the middle of the crag.

content.description:
Good climbing on the uphill arete of The Cube boulder.  Look for the good holds as you stand higher and higher. The hands aren't mega, but the feet are so good that you end up being very secure for the duration of this climb.

It's cool, too, because it has a more open feel than the climbs to the left, The Segment and Tron.
content.protection: Tough to protect so that falls would be ok. You could place a pad nearby for controlled bailout, but I think this is a more controlled do not fall kind of problem.
content.location: Just left of The Cube face, on the higher arete.

content.description: Start on obvious holds, find your way into the generous steep flake and mantle after some strenuous laybacking.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, nice flat landing.
content.location: On the large boulder at the NE corner of the crag.

content.description: Stand start on the crimps you can reach, delicate and balancey climbing on more crimps from there to an easy mantle. Book says V5 but once you figure out the beta it feels a bit soft for the grade. That said, the sequence can be confusing at first.
content.location: First boulder you encounter on the left of the trail as you walk to the cube. If you are standing in front of the obvious crack on the large face of the cube boulder and turn left, you're looking at pentaphobia.

content.description: As quoted from the guidebook "this dynamic problem climbs the right arete of the first boulder at clamshell. Pull on using a good pinch/crimp on the arete and a small lefthand sidepull on the face. Slap to the grainy sloper and finish up the corner. Stiff for the grade"
content.location: On the same boulder as "Pentaphobia"

content.description: Climb the left corner of the Gandalf boulder from a sit start. Go up and left and good holds
content.location: The left side of the Gandalf boulder next to the CCST boulder. It's the only problem that goes into the backside of the boulder, and it starts on the hill unlike the others

content.description: Climb straight up with nice edges to finish on the left of the arete.
content.location: Slightly below and next to the Crimp, Crimp, Slap, Throw boulder, there is another tall teardrop shaped boulder. This problem is on the side facing the CCST boulder. It is also just to the left of Gandalf.

content.description: Start on edges on the right side of the boulder, then traverse left to top out as for Crimp Crimp Slap Throw on the left arete.
content.location: Right end of the Crimp Crimp Slap Throw boulder, about 100 feet to the left of the main Cube boulder area when facing uphill.

content.description: Climb the left arete of the scooped off-vertical face. Feels higher than it looks. Downclimb the backside with the help of a tree.
content.location: The middle of the boulder slightly below the Crimp, Crimp, Slap, Throw boulder.

content.description: Using good left foot step onto the slab after som strechy moves find the jugs that lead to an easy topout.  Kind of easy for V1 but has a committing move or two.
content.location: The west side of the Gandalf boulder which is at the west corner of the crag.

content.description: Big, committing, and there are actual moves at the 15 foot mark. Bring your big gestational organs.
content.protection: I think the safest way to do this would be to bring a friend(s) and 2-3 pads. I did not have this, but it should be possile to somewhat protect the high crux, at least from serious injury. The best thing would be to up and down climb until you've got it sorted, and then commit.
content.location: The big clean, western face of the boulder.

content.description: If you don't want to do the Cube Crack roof, and you do want to do a silly traverse and the 5.7 crack above, this is your line. Start right of the crack on good underclings, and go left until you hit the crack. Straight up from there. The rock is good, but this line feels forced, and doesn't match the quality of the others around.
content.location: See description above.

content.description: A hard first 6 feet lead to easier, but still technical vertical crack climbing above. Start with decent hands and one third of the way out of the cave, and make a couple of very crack technique intensive moves to get through the roof and over the lip. I suppose you could power it as well, since you are a boulderer, but don't expect it to feel v2 if you do.
content.location: Just around the corner from The Cube face, look for the big obvious 5.7 crack, that wraps below to form a cool roof.

content.description: Tricky stand start on small crimps at about chest height. Move up to better crimp, find a foot, then slap up on the slopey arÃªte. Finish with a fun throw to the final jug and an easy mantel.
content.location: Near the Lord of the Rings boulder on the opposite side of the clamshell area from the cube boulder. Boulder is identifiable by a hand crack (cleaver crack V0) running up the center of the face. Problem is on the left side of the boulder.

content.description: Climb the hand crack I also used a pinch about halfway up.
content.location: On the Crimp Crimp boulder at the west side of the crag
